Literature Review:
Induced resistance in fruits and vegetables is a promising strategy for controlling postharvest diseases, which are primarily caused by fungal pathogens. This approach involves the activation of the plant's own defense mechanisms, thereby reducing the reliance on chemical fungicides and enhancing the sustainability of postharvest management practices. The concept of induced resistance is rooted in the plant's ability to recognize pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) and subsequently activate a cascade of defense responses (Walters et al., 2005). These responses include the production of pathogenesis-related proteins, phytoalexins, and the strengthening of cell walls, all of which contribute to the inhibition of pathogen growth and spread (Hammerschmidt, 1999).

One of the key physiological processes involved in induced resistance is the modulation of ripening and senescence. Ripening is associated with increased respiration and ethylene production, which can compromise the fruit's defense mechanisms and make it more susceptible to pathogen attack (Giovannoni, 2004). By delaying ripening, induced resistance can maintain the fruit in a state of heightened defense readiness. This is achieved through the application of elicitors, which are compounds that mimic pathogen attack and trigger the plant's defense responses. For example, treatments with salicylic acid, jasmonic acid, and ethylene have been shown to enhance resistance in various fruits and vegetables by modulating the expression of defense-related genes (Khan et al., 2003).

The effectiveness of induced resistance is also influenced by the maturity and ripening stage of the host. Fruits and vegetables at different stages of development exhibit varying levels of susceptibility to pathogens, with immature fruits generally being more resistant than ripe ones (Prusky, 1996). This is due to the higher levels of phenolic compounds and other secondary metabolites in immature fruits, which have antimicrobial properties. Therefore, the timing of elicitor application is crucial for maximizing the benefits of induced resistance. Studies have shown that applying elicitors at the early stages of ripening can significantly enhance the fruit's resistance to postharvest pathogens (Terry and Joyce, 2004).

In addition to delaying ripening, induced resistance can also enhance the production of phenolic compounds and antioxidants, which are important for both defense and quality. Phenolic compounds, such as flavonoids and tannins, have been shown to inhibit the growth of a wide range of fungal pathogens (Lattanzio et al., 2006). Moreover, these compounds contribute to the nutritional and sensory quality of the produce, making them more appealing to consumers. Antioxidants, on the other hand, help to mitigate oxidative stress, which is a common consequence of pathogen attack and can lead to cellular damage and spoilage (Apel and Hirt, 2004).

Recent advances in molecular biology and omics technologies have provided new insights into the mechanisms underlying induced resistance. Transcriptomic and proteomic analyses have identified key genes and proteins involved in the defense response, allowing for the development of more targeted and effective elicitor treatments (Alkan et al., 2015). Furthermore, the use of biocontrol agents, such as beneficial microbes, has emerged as a complementary strategy to enhance induced resistance. These microbes can colonize the fruit surface and produce antimicrobial compounds, as well as induce systemic resistance in the host (Droby et al., 2009).

Despite the promising potential of induced resistance, there are still challenges that need to be addressed. One of the main limitations is the variability in response among different fruit and vegetable species, as well as among different cultivars within a species. This variability can be attributed to genetic differences in the regulation of defense pathways and the presence of specific receptors for elicitors (Vallad and Goodman, 2004). Therefore, further research is needed to identify the genetic and environmental factors that influence the expression of induced resistance and to develop tailored strategies for different crops.

In conclusion, induced resistance represents a viable and sustainable approach to managing postharvest diseases in fruits and vegetables. By enhancing the plant's natural defense mechanisms, it offers a means to reduce postharvest losses and improve the quality and shelf life of produce. Continued research into the underlying mechanisms and the development of novel elicitors and biocontrol agents will be essential for optimizing this strategy and ensuring its widespread adoption in the agricultural industry.
